text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: This report describes a Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) prepared by JLB Traffic Engineering, Inc. (JLB) for the
proposed Harbor House Apartments (Project) in the City of Clovis. The Project proposes to develop 47
multi-family units on approximately 3.2 acres. The Project will be located at the northeast corner of
Ashlan and Temperance Avenues. Per information provided to JLB, the Project is consistent with the City
of Clovis General Plan. Figure 1 shows the location of the proposed project site relative to the surrounding
The purpose of this TIA is to evaluate the potential traffic impacts, identify short-term roadway and
circulation needs, determine potential mitigation measures and identify any critical traffic issues that
should be addressed in the on-going planning process. The study primarily focused on evaluating traffic
conditions at study intersections, which may be impacted by the proposed Project. The scope of work was
prepared via consultation with the City of Clovis, City of Fresno, County of Fresno and Caltrans staff.
The potential impacts of the proposed Project were evaluated in accordance with the standards set forth
by the level of service (LOS) policy of the City of Clovis.
At present the study intersections operate at LOS D or better during both the a.m. and p.m. peak
Queuing was observed to be minor on all approaches, during both peak periods. However, on one
occasion during the a.m. peak period, at the intersection of Ashlan Avenue and Temperance
Avenue the queues on the westbound thru lanes extended approximately 300 feet.
Under this scenario, the study intersections are projected to continue operating at LOS D or better
during both the a.m. and p.m. peak hours.
JLB qualitatively analyzed the proposed driveway to Ashlan Avenue and determined that it is
located at a point that minimizes traffic operational impacts to the existing street network.
It is recommended that the proposed reciprocal emergency access point to Hanson Avenue should
be gated and locked with locks controlled by emergency personal only.
Queuing at some of the approach lanes is projected to increase slightly or remain largely
unchanged. The existing storage capacity of the existing turn lanes are projected to accommodate
The un-signalized intersection of Ashlan Avenue at Carson Avenue is not projected to meet traffic

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions
Existing plus Project with Added U-turn Pocket Traffic Conditions

page.text: This Scenario examines the Existing plus Project traffic conditions under the assumption that a
median island opening is added on Ashlan Avenue at a point approximately midway between
Temperance and Carson Avenues. The purpose of the median island opening is to allow eastbound
to westbound U-turns to take place at this median opening and not at Carson Avenue where they
would take place in the absence of the added U-turn pocket.
Under this scenario, the study intersections are projected to continue operating at LOS D or
better during both the a.m. and p.m. peak hours.
The un-signalized intersection of Ashlan Avenue at Carson Avenue is not projected to meet signal
The introduction of the added eastbound U-turn median opening on Ashlan Avenue will slightly
improve queuing at the intersection of Ashlan Avenue and Carson Avenue, but the LOS results will
Based on a comparison of the LOS results between this scenario and that of the Existing plus
Project without the added eastbound U-turn pocket; the introduction of the eastbound U-turn
median island opening is not recommended as it is not projected to significantly change traffic
operations at the study intersections. However, the decision to add the eastbound U-turn would
need to be made by the City of Clovis.

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The project site and surrounding study area are illustrated in Figure 1. Important roadways serving the
Ashlan Avenue is an existing east-west four-lane divided roadway in the vicinity of the Project. At present
Ashlan Avenue extends from Watts Valley Road westerly through the City of Clovis and City of Fresno. The
1993 Clovis General Plan Circulation Element designates Ashlan Avenue as a four lane divided arterial.
Temperance Avenue is an existing four-lane roadway adjacent to the proposed Project site. At present
Temperance Avenue extends from Shepherd Avenue southerly through the City of Clovis and City of
Fresno. The 1993 Clovis General Plan Circulation Element designates this segment of Temperance Avenue
as a four lane divided expressway.
Carson Avenue is an existing two-lane local residential roadway in the vicinity to the proposed Project site.
Level of Service (LOS) is a qualitative index of the performance of an element of the transportation system.
LOS is a rating scale running from “A” to “F”, with “A” indicating no congestion of any kind, and “F”
indicating unacceptable congestion and delays. LOS in this study describes the operating conditions for
The 2010 Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) is the standard reference published by the Transportation
Research Board, and contains the specific criteria and methods to be used in assessing LOS. Synchro
software was used to define LOS in this study. Details regarding these calculations are in Appendix A.
The 1993 Clovis General Plan has established LOS D as the acceptable level of service threshold on its
major streets. LOS D was used to evaluate the potential significance of level of service impacts to City of

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The following operational analysis assumptions and defaults were used in this study:
Yellow time consistent with the California Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices (CA MUTCD)
All red clearance intervals of 1.0 second for all phases;
Flashing Don’t Walk based on 3.5 feet/second walking speed, with yellow plus all-red clearance
All new or modified signals utilize protected left turn phasing;
At existing intersections, the observed Peak Hour Factor (PHF) is utilized in the Existing, and
New proposed study facilities utilize a PHF of 0.92 as recommended by the Highway Capacity
An average of 3 pedestrian calls per hour at signalized intersections.
These default values also ensure a consistent analysis of LOS among the various scenarios.
The study focused on evaluating traffic conditions at study intersections that may potentially be impacted
by the proposed Project. On April 28, 2014, a draft scope of work for the preparation of a traffic impact
analysis for this Project was provided to the City of Fresno, County of Fresno and Caltrans for their review
and comment. The draft scope of work was based on communication with City of Clovis staff. On April 29,
2014 Caltrans indicated that they had reviewed the scope of work and that it was acceptable as
presented. On May 9, 2014 the City of Fresno indicated that they had no comments to the scope of work.
JLB staff contacted the County of Fresno via phone and emails regarding the scope of work for the
preparation of this TIA but the County did not provide comments. It should be noted that it is the County’s
practice to require the analysis of County intersections for which a Project is anticipated to have 10 or
more peak hour trips to it; and segments which the Project is anticipated to have 100 or more daily trips.
Based on the Project’s trip generation and distribution not one intersection or roadway segment in the
County’s jurisdiction is projected to have ten or more peak our trips or 100 or more daily trips at an
intersection of segment respectively. A copy of the proposed draft scope of work is contained in Appendix
B. The study intersections are shown in Figure 1.
The study focused on evaluating traffic conditions at the existing study intersections that may potentially
be impacted by the proposed project. New traffic counts were collected for the study intersections on
April 30, 2014. The traffic counts for the existing study intersections are contained in Appendix C. The
existing turning movement volumes, lane geometrics, and intersection controls are illustrated in Figure 1.
3. Ashlan Avenue / Proposed Median Opening for Eastbound U-turns

from Figure 4 to the previous scenario. The Project only trips to the study intersections was based on a
Fresno COG “Select Zone” run, the existing roadway network, and Engineering judgment. The Fresno COG
Model request and Select Zone Analysis are contained in Appendix D.

page.text: City of Clovis - Harbor House Apartments TIA
Existing - Traffic Volumes, Geometrics and Controls

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The Harbor House Apartment Project proposes to develop 47 multi-family units on approximately 3.2
acres. The Project will be located at the northeast corner of Ashlan and Temperance Avenues. Per
information provided to JLB, the project is consistent with the City of Clovis General Plan. Figure 1 shows
the location of the proposed project site relative to the surrounding roadway network. Figure 3 illustrates
the proposed site plan and its anticipated project driveway trips.
Access to and from the project site will be provided via one access point to Ashlan Avenue at a point
approximately 230 feet east of Temperance Avenue. This access point will be limited to right in and right
out access. An emergency only access point will be provided to and from Hanson Avenue a local
residential cul-de-sac. Additional details are found on the site plan shown on Figure 3.
JLB qualitatively analyzed the location of the proposed access point relative to the existing local roads and
driveways in the Project’s vicinity. A review of these indicates that the proposed driveway to Ashlan
Avenue is located at a point that minimizes traffic operational impacts to the existing street network. The
proposed emergency access only point should be gated and locked with locks controlled by emergency
Currently, bike lanes exist adjacent to the proposed project site and in its vicinity. The existing bike lanes
are on Ashlan and Temperance Avenues. The existing bike lanes are in conformance with the City of Clovis
bicycle lane requirements for the City’s major street system.
Trip generation for the proposed project is based on information provided by the developer and the
Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) reference, Trip Generation, 9th Edition. Table II below provides
the trip generation for the proposed project. Upon buildout, the Project is estimated to generate a
maximum of 313 daily, 24 a.m., and 29 p.m. peak hour trips.

text.b: Table II: Project Only Trip Generation

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The trip distribution assumptions were developed based on existing travel patterns, data provided by the
developer, knowledge of the study area, the Fresno COG Select Zone Analysis and the City’s General Plan
Circulation Element. Project trips were assigned to the study facilities based on these assumptions. Figure
4 illustrates the Project Only trip assignment to the study intersections.
Clovis Transit Stageline is the transit operator in the City of Clovis. At present, there are no transit routes
operating in the vicinity of the proposed project. The closest route to the Project is Transit Route 50 and
its nearest stop to the project site is located at the northwest corner of Ashlan and Fowler Avenues
(approximately one mile to the west). Retention of the existing and expansion of future transit routes is
dependent on transit ridership demand and on available funding.
Results of Levels of Service, Intersection Geometrics and Controls
The Existing plus Project turning movement volumes, intersection geometrics, and traffic controls are
illustrated in Figure 5. This scenario assumes that the existing roadway geometrics and traffic controls will
remain in place. The study intersection levels of service calculation results are contained in Appendix F.
Table III summarizes the levels of service results under this scenario.

text.b: Table III: Existing plus Project Intersection LOS Results

Peak hour traffic signal warrants as appropriate were prepared for the Existing plus Project Conditions
scenario. These warrants are found in Appendix H. The effects of right turning traffic from the minor
approach onto the major approach were taken into account using engineering judgment pursuant to the
CA MUTCD guidelines for the preparation of traffic signal warrants. Under this scenario, the existing un-
signalized study intersection is not projected to satisfy peak hour traffic signal warrants.

page.text: Existing plus Project with Added Eastbound U-turn Pocket Conditions
This scenario assumes that a median island opening would be built along Ashlan Avenue between
Applegate Avenue and Carson Avenue concurrently with the Project. With the added median island
opening it is anticipated that all eastbound to westbound U-turns that would otherwise utilize the
intersection of Ashlan Avenue at Carson Avenue would be relocated to this point as such would be the
simplest and most direct path to the Project site. With the introduction of the median island opening, it is
also anticipated that the existing eastbound to westbound U-turns at Carson Avenue would also be
relocated to the new median island opening as such would have less conflict points and would also be a
Figure 6 illustrates the Existing plus Project with Added Eastbound U-turn Pocket Project Only Trip
Assignment. While Figure 7 illustrates the Existing plus Project with Added Eastbound U-turn Pocket total
traffic volumes, geometrics and traffic controls at the study intersections. The intersection levels of service
calculation results are contained in Appendix F. Table IV summarizes the levels of service at the study
The introduction of the added eastbound U-turn pocket on Ashlan Avenue will slightly improve queuing at
the intersection of Ashlan Avenue and Carson Avenue, but the LOS results will largely remain unchanged.
Based on a comparison of the LOS results between of the Existing plus Project and the Existing plus Project
with Added Eastbound U-turn Pocket, the introduction of the eastbound U-turn pocket is not
recommended. However, the final decision to add the eastbound U-turn pocket would need to be made
by the City of Clovis as the lead agency.
If upon the review of this TIA and other data readily available to the City it is decided that an Eastbound U-
turn pocket will be built as a requirement of the Project, then the following design parameters should be
The storage length of the U-turn pocket should be 50 feet;
The bay taper in advance of the U-turn pocket should be a minimum of 90 feet; and
The median island opening should be located approximately midway between Temperance and

page.text: Peak hour traffic signal warrants as appropriate were prepared for the Existing plus Project with Added
Eastbound U-turn Pocket conditions scenario. These warrants are found in Appendix H. The effects of
right turning traffic from the minor approach onto the major approach were taken into account using
engineering judgment pursuant to the CA MUTCD guidelines for the preparation of traffic signal warrants.
Under this scenario, the existing un-signalized study intersection does not satisfy peak hour traffic signal
Table V provides a queue length summary for left and right turn lanes at the study intersections for the
Existing, Existing plus Project, and Existing plus Project with Added U-turn Pocket scenarios. The queuing
analyses for the study intersections are contained in the LOS worksheets for the respective scenarios.
* = Does not exist or is not projected to exist
Queuing analyses were completed using Sim Traffic output information. Synchro provides both
50th and 95th percentile maximum queue lengths in feet. According to the Synchro manual, “the 50th
percentile maximum queue is the maximum back of queue on a typical cycle and the
95th percentile queue is the maximum back of queue with 95th percentile volumes.” The queues shown
on Table V are the 95th percentile queue lengths for the respective lane movements.
Based on the queuing analysis for the Existing and Existing plus Project scenarios the existing left and right
turn storage lengths are projected to accommodate the queuing demand. Should the introduction of a
median island opening on Ashlan Avenue be pursued then it is recommended that the storage capacity for
the eastbound U-turn pocket be set to a minimum of 50 feet with a minimum bay taper length of 90 feet.

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning, & Parking Solutions
Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The description and procedures for calculating capacity and level of service (LOS) are found in the
Transportation Research Board, Highway Capacity Manual (HCM). The HCM 2010 represents the
research on capacity and quality of service for transportation facilities.
Quality of service requires quantitative measures to characterize operational conditions within a traffic
stream. Level of service is a quality measure describing operational conditions within a traffic stream,
generally in terms of such service measures as speed and travel time, freedom to maneuver, traffic
Six levels of service are defined for each type of facility that has analysis procedures available. Letters
designate each level of service (LOS), from A to F, with LOS A representing the best operating conditions
and LOS F the worst. Each LOS represents a range of operating conditions and the driver’s perception of
these conditions. Safety is not included in the measures that establish a LOS.
The term “urban streets” refers to urban arterials and collectors, including those in downtown areas.
Arterial streets are roads that primarily serve longer through trips. However, providing access to
abutting commercial and residential land uses is also an important function of arterials. Collector streets
provide both land access and traffic circulation within residential, commercial and industrial areas. Their
access function is more important than that of arterials, and unlike arterials their operation is not always
dominated by traffic signals. Downtown streets are signalized facilities that often resemble arterials.
They not only move through traffic but also provide access to local businesses for passenger cars, transit
buses, and trucks. Pedestrian conflicts and lane obstructions created by stopping or standing taxicabs,
buses, trucks and parking vehicles that cause turbulence in the traffic flow are typical of downtown
The speed of vehicles on urban streets is influenced by three main factors, street environment,
interaction among vehicles and traffic control.
The street environment includes the geometric characteristics of the facility, the character of roadside
activity, and adjacent land uses. Thus, the environment reflects the number and width of lanes, type of
median, driveway/access point density, spacing between signalized intersections, existence of parking,
level of pedestrian and bicyclist activity and speed limit.
The interaction among vehicles is determined by traffic density, the proportion of trucks and buses, and
turning movements. This interaction affects the operation of vehicles at intersections and, to a lesser
Traffic controls (including signals and signs) forces a portion of all vehicles to slow or stop. The delays
and speed changes caused by traffic control devices reduce vehicle speeds; however, such controls are

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The average travel speed for through vehicles along an urban street is the determinant of the operating
level of service (LOS). The travel speed along a segment, section or entire length of an urban street is
dependent on the running speed between signalized intersections and the amount of control delay
LOS A describes primarily free-flow operation. Vehicles are completely unimpeded in their ability to
maneuver within the traffic stream. Control delay at signalized intersections is minimal. Travel speeds
exceed 85 of the base free flow speed (FFS).
LOS B describes reasonably unimpeded operation. The ability to maneuver within the traffic stream is
only slightly restricted and control delay at the boundary intersections is not significant. The travel
speed is between 67 and 85 percent of the base FFS.
LOS C describes stable operations. The ability to maneuver and change lanes in midblock location may
be more restricted than at LOS B. Longer queues at the boundary intersections may contribute to lower
travel speeds. The travel speed is between 50 and 67 percent of the base FFS.
LOS D indicates a less stable condition in which small increases in flow may cause substantial increases
in delay and decreases in travel speed. This operation may be due to adverse signal progression, high
volumes, inappropriate signal timing, at the boundary intersections. The travel speed is between 40 and
LOS E is characterized unstable operation and significant delay. Such operations may be due to some
combination of adverse progression, high volume, and inappropriate signal timing at the boundary
intersections. The travel speed is between 30 and 40 percent of the base FFS.
LOS F is characterized by street flow at extremely low speed. Congestion is likely occurring at the
boundary intersections, as indicated by high delay and extensive queuing. The travel speed is 30 percent
or less of the base FFS.

text.b: Table A-1: Urban Street Levels of Service (Automobile Mode)
Travel Speed as a Percentage of Base Free-Flow Speed (%)

text.i: = The Critical volume-to-capacity ratio is based on consideration of the through movement-to-capacity ratio at each boundary
intersection in the subject direction of travel. The critical volume-to-capacity ratio is the largest ratio of those considered.
Source: Highway Capacity Manual 2010, Exhibit 16-4. Urban Street LOS Criteria (Automobile Mode)
Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: One of the more important elements limiting, and often interrupting the flow of traffic on a highway is
the intersection. Flow on an interrupted facility is usually dominated by points of fixed operation such as
traffic signals, stop and yield signs.
For signalized intersections the performance measures include automobile volume-to-capacity ratio,
automobile delay, queue storage length, ratio of pedestrian delay, pedestrian circulation area,
pedestrian perception score, bicycle delay, and bicycle perception score. LOS is also considered a
performance measure. For the automobile mode average control delay per vehicle per approach is
determined for the peak hour. A weighted average of control delay per vehicle is then determined for
the intersection. A LOS designation is given to the weighted average control delay to better describe the
level of operation. A description of LOS for signalized intersections is found in Table A-2.

text.b: Table A-2: Signalized Intersection Level of Service Description (Automobile Mode)

page.text: Operations with a control delay of 10 seconds/vehicle or less and a volume-to-capacity
ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when volume-to-capacity ratio is
and either progression is exceptionally favorable or the cycle length is very short. If it’s
due to favorable progression, most vehicles arrive during the green indication and travel
Operations with control delay between 10.1 to 20.0 seconds/vehicle and a volume-to-
capacity ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when the volume-to-
capacity ratio is low and either progression is highly favorable or the cycle length is short.
More vehicles stop than with LOS A.
Operations with average control delays between 20.1 to 35.0 seconds/vehicle and a
volume-to-capacity ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when the
volume-to-capacity ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when
progression is favorable or the cycle length is moderate. Individual cycle failures (i.e., one
or more queued vehicles are not able to depart as a result of insufficient capacity during the
cycle) may begin to appear at this level. The number of vehicles stopping is significant,
although many vehicles still pass through the intersection without stopping.
Operations with control delay between 35.1 to 55.0 seconds/vehicle and a volume-to-
capacity ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when the volume-to-
capacity ratio is high and either progression is ineffective or the cycle length is long.
Many vehicles stop, and i ndividual cycle failures are noticeable.
control delay between 55.1 to 80.0 seconds/vehicle and a volume-to-
capacity ratio no greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when the volume-to-
capacity ratio is high, progression is unfavorable, and the cycle length is long. Individual
volume-to-capacity ratio greater than 1.0. This level is typically assigned when the
volume-to-capacity ratio is very high, progression is very poor, and the cycle length is
long. Most cycles fail to clear the queue.

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: The HCM 2010 procedures use control delay as a measure of effectiveness to determine level of service.
Delay is a measure of driver discomfort, frustration, fuel consumption, and increased travel time. The
delay experienced by a motorist is made up of a number of factors that relate to control, traffic and
incidents. Total delay is the difference between the travel time actually experienced and the reference
travel time that would result during base conditions, i. e., in the absence of traffic control, geometric
delay, any incidents, and any other vehicles. Control delay is the increased time of travel for a vehicle
approaching and passing through an unsignalized intersection, compared with a free-flow vehicle if it
were not required to slow or stop at the intersection.
All-way stop controlled intersections is a form of traffic controls in which all approaches to an
intersection are required to stop. Similar to signalized intersections, at all-way stop controlled
intersections the average control delay per vehicle per approach is determined for the peak hour. A
weighted average of control delay per vehicle is then determined for the intersection as a whole. In
other words the delay measured for all-way stop controlled intersections is a measure of the average
delay for all vehicles passing through the intersection during the peak hour. A LOS designation is given to
the weighted average control delay to better describe the level of operation.
Two-way stop controlled (TWSC) intersections in which stop signs are used to assign the right-of-way,
are the most prevalent type of intersection in the United States. At TWSC intersections the stop-
controlled approaches are referred as the minor street approaches and can be either public streets or
private driveways. The approaches that are not controlled by stop signs are referred to as the major
The capacity of movements subject to delay are determined using the "critical gap" method of capacity
analysis. Expected average control delay based on movement volume and movement capacity is
calculated. A LOS for TWSC intersection is determined by the computed or measured control delay for
each minor movement. LOS is not defined for the intersection as a whole for three main reasons: (a)
major-street through vehicles are assumed to experience zero delay; (b) the disproportionate number of
major-street through vehicles at the typical TWSC intersection skews the weighted average of all
movements, resulting in a very low overall average delay from all vehicles; and (c) the resulting low
delay can mask important LOS deficiencies for minor movements. Table A-3 provides a description of

i.b: Table A-3: Unsignalized Intersection Level of Service Description (Automobile Mode)

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

text.b: Appendix B: TIA Draft Scope of Work

text.i: Traffic Engineering, transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

text.b: Proposed Draft Scope of Work for the Preparation of a Traffic Impact Analysis
for the Proposed Development of the Northeast Corner of Temperance and
Ashlan Avenues in the City of Clovis (JLB Project 006-002)

page.text: JLB Traffic Engineering, Inc. (JLB) hereby submits this Draft Scope of Work for the preparation of a
Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) for the Harbor House Apartment complex project. The Harbor House
Apartment Project proposes to develop 47 multi-family units on approximately 3.2 acres. The project
will be generally located at the northeast corner of Temperance and Ashlan Avenues. Per information
provided to JLB, the project is consistent with the City of Clovis General Plan. An aerial of the project
vicinity and the project site plan are shown in Exhibits A and B respectively. The purpose of this TIA is
to evaluate the potential on and off-site traffic impacts, identify short-term roadway and circulation
needs, determine potential mitigation measures, and identify any critical traffic issues that should be
addressed in the on-going planning process. In order to evaluate the on and off-site traffic impacts of
the proposed project, JLB proposes the following draft scope of work.
Request a Fresno County Council of Governments (Fresno COG) traffic forecast model run for the
project (Select Zone Analysis) which will include the project and the streets to be analyzed. The
Fresno COG traffic forecasting model will be used to forecast traffic volumes for the Base Year
JLB will evaluate existing and forecast levels of service (LOS) at the study intersection(s) and/or
segment(s). JLB will use Synchro to perform this analysis for the a.m. and p.m. peak hours. JLB will
identify the causes of poor LOS.
Evaluate onsite circulation and provide recommendations as necessary to improve circulation to the
site and within the project site.
As necessary obtain recent or schedule and conduct new traffic counts at the study facility (ies).
Perform a site visit to observe existing traffic conditions, especially during the a.m. and p.m. peak
hours. Existing roadway conditions, including geometrics and traffic controls, will be verified.
Forecast trip distribution based on turn count information, input from Fresno COG staff, proposed
school boundaries, and knowledge of the existing and planned circulation network in the vicinity of

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: Harbor House Apartments TIA Draft Scope of Work
1. Existing traffic conditions with proposed mitigation measures (if any); and
2. Existing plus Project traffic conditions with proposed mitigation measures (if any).

text.b: Weekday peak hours to be analyzed:

page.text: 3. Ashlan Avenue / Proposed EB Left turn Pocket between Temperance and Carson Avenues
Queuing analysis is included in the proposed scope of work for the study intersection(s) listed above
under all study scenarios. This analysis will be utilized to recommend minimum storage lengths for
left and right turn lanes at all study intersections.
Trip generation for the proposed project is based on information provided by the developer and the
Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) reference, Trip Generation, 9th Edition. Table I below provides
the trip generation for the proposed project.

text.b: Table I – Project Only Trip Generation

page.text: Access to and from the project site will be provided via one access point to Ashlan Avenue at a point
approximately 230 feet east of Temperance Avenue. This access point will be limited to right in and
right out access. An emergency only access point will be provided from a local residential cul-de-sac, but
for purposes of the select zone analysis all trips to and from the project site are to use the Ashlan
Avenue access point. Additional details are found on the site plan shown on Exhibit B.

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: Harbor House Apartments TIA Draft Scope of Work
The above scope of work is based on our understanding of this project and our experience with similar
Traffic Impact Analysis projects. In the absence of comments by May 19, 2014, we will assume that the
above scope of work is acceptable to the agency (ies) that have not submitted any comments to the
proposed TIA scope of work. If you have any questions or require additional information, please contact
me at (559) 570-8991 or by email at
Jill Gormley, P.E., City of Fresno
Bryan Araki, Acting Deputy City Planner, City of Clovis

text.b: Appendix D: Model Request and Select Zone

text.i: Traffic Engineering, transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

text.b: Traffic Modeling Request for the Preparation of a Traffic Impact Analysis for
the Proposed Development of the Northeast Corner of Temperance and
Ashlan Avenues in the City of Clovis (JLB Project 006-002)

page.text: JLB Traffic Engineering, Inc. (JLB) hereby requests traffic modeling for the project described below. The
project proposes to develop 47 multi-family units on approximately 3.2 acres. The project will be
generally located at the northeast corner of Temperance and Ashlan Avenues. Per information provided
to JLB by the City of Clovis, the project is consistent with the City of Clovis General Plan. An aerial of
the project vicinity and the project site plan are shown in Exhibits A and B respectively.
1. Base Year 2014 (with Link and TAZ modifications)
2. Cumulative Year 2035 Plus Project Select Zone (with Link and TAZ modifications)
3. Differences between model runs 2 and 1 above

text.b: Changes and/or additions to the Model Network or TAZ’s

page.text: TJKM reviewed the Fresno COG model network for the base year 2014 and cumulative year 2035. Based
on this review, JLB requests the following link and TAZ network modifications.
1. Ashlan Avenue between Armstrong Avenue and Temperance Avenue should be modified to
include two (2) lanes in each direction divided by a raised concrete median. This would be
consistent with the current lane geometrics of Ashlan Avenue.
1. Create Project TAZ 737A from existing TAZ 737. TAZ 737A should have one TAZ connector.
The TAZ connector should be south to Ashlan Avenue at a point approximately 230 feet east of
2. Eliminate TAZ connector from TAZ 737 to Temperance Avenue
3. Retain all other the existing TAZ connectors from the original TAZ

text.i: Traffic Engineering, Transportation Planning & Parking Solutions

page.text: Trip generation for the proposed project is based on information provided by the developer and the
Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) reference, Trip Generation, 9th Edition. Table I below provides
the trip generation for the proposed project.

text.b: Table I – Project Only Trip Generation

page.text: Access to and from the project site will be provided via one access point to Ashlan Avenue at a point
approximately 230 feet east of Temperance Avenue. This access point will be limited to right in and
right out access. An emergency only access point will be provided from a local residential cul-de-sac, but
for purposes of the select zone analysis all trips to and from the project site are to use the Ashlan
Avenue access point. Additional details are found on the site plan shown on Exhibit B.
JLB is performing the traffic impact analysis on behalf of the City of Clovis. As the City of Clovis is a
member agency of Fresno COG we have assumed that all modeling work to be done by Fresno COG
will be done at no expense to JLB. Our primary Client contact with the City of Clovis is Mr. Mike
Harrison P.E. If you have any questions or require additional information, please contact me at (559)
Bryan Araki, Acting Deputy City Planner, City of Clovis
Mike Harrison P.E., City of Clovis
